title: ; ; READERS WRITE
body:
Regarding "County mulls solutions as guns spike in schools" (News, Sept. 29), where children are getting guns was 
never asked or addressed. My educated guess is these underage children are getting them from their homes. 
Responsible gun ownership, especially if children are in the home, is part of the solution to gun violence including 
unintentional shootings and suicides. There is a program, "Be SMART For Children," which teaches adults to 
secure all guns; model responsible behavior; ask about the presence of guns in other homes; recognize the role of 
guns in suicide; and tell peers to be smart. You can contact the Moms Demand Action-Georgia chapter to get more 
information and even a Be SMART presentation for your organization. Responsible gun ownership is not a political 
issue. It is common sense and can save lives.

JULIE KIMBALL, SUWANEE

Letters shouldn't be edged out by editorials

So AJC, you are now using the letters section to publish editorials. If you want to editorialize, you have plenty of 
space. You constantly print self-adoration throughout the paper, occasionally full-page. Readers don't need your 
"Look how great we are" comments. The "Our View" of Oct. 11, "Heartbreak aside, Braves, fans should look to 
future," took the cake. Who cares if a baseball team wins or loses? How does that have any lasting meaning to our 
lives? If you want to do away with the letters to the editor, just say so and do it! Overall, you are edging closer and 
closer to becoming just another supermarket checkout-counter rag. Please, go back to what you should be -- a real 
newspaper. That's what you were when I became a damn Yankee in 1991 and started reading your paper.

DAN SIEGEL, DACULA

Letters to the editor must be no longer than 150 words and must include a daytime phone number for 
verification.Letters will be edited for length and clarity and may be published in both print and digital formats. 
Emailed submissions are strongly preferred. Please email to: letters@ajc.com

About the Opinion page: The AJC recognizes the diversity and differences of opinion among our readership, and 
we strive to accommodate this reality by offering both conservative and liberal opinion voices each day.And we 
recognize the variety of opinions even within the same side of the political aisle, and hope you do too.For example, 
some of our liberal writers have been critical of former President Barack Obama--much as some of our conservative 
columnists have criticized President Donald Trump, while others generally support him.We're continually looking at 
how best to bring you that breadth of opinion and balance both left and right, in print and online.
